Reviews.Title: Beautiful screen in a high powered desktop replacement.
Reviews.Author: Justin Carlson
Reviews.Content: PROS:*Excellent High Resolution IPS Screen (Zero bright pixel warranty)*Premium build quality*Very quiet and hidden exhaust vents out the hinge*Quad core i7 2.4ghz - 3.4ghz (Haswell)*1600mhz 1.35v RAM (Mine came with a single 8GB stick and an empty slot for more)*Large 1TB Hard drive*Touchscreen*CD/DVD Drive (Many laptops are removing these)*1 Year accidental damage warranty*Included subwoofer*Large click pad with windows 8 gestures that works very well*Backlit Full Sized keyboard (Adjustable Brightness)CONS:*Speakers can sound muffled as they are facing down just under the front of the palmrest.*Hard Drive is slow (5400rpm) and there is no mSATA slot for a small SSD. However, using an adapter (sold separately), you can replace the DVD drive with an 2.5mm Hard Drive or SSD.*Squished Number Pad (But I would rather have this than a smaller keyboard)NOTE: A couple posted specs are wrong. It has Intel HD4600 graphics and it does NOT weigh 20lbs.

Reviews.Title: Win 8 touch screen
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I have been using the Asus for 2 weeks now and think it is a good quality build, so far. I am not yet familiar with win 8 and touch screen and I believe there is a decent learning curve that I have not scaled. I am used to win 7 and 8 is very different. The tiles dropping down can be annoying when using the mouse. Fortunately desktop mode is familiar win 7 format so I can learn win 8 at my pace.The problem I have with the N550JA, and the reason for this review, is the keyboard design is BAD. It is a wonderful lighted keyboard that is fantastic if you work at night, but it is silver with white inscriptions that can b very difficult to see in daylight. The Asus backlight black keyboard is 1000% better. The reason for a lighted keyboard has been foiled with this design. I used to have a problem at night, now night is fine and I can't see during the day...urgh!Update:I was so wrong! fn13, fn14 are the function keys to adjust backlight. Turn backlight down in daylight and there is no problem at all. oops!

Reviews.Title: Asus laptop, The best.
Reviews.Author: KAREL CASO
Reviews.Content: A+++ laptop excellent quality, beautiful exterior and interior design, very fast computer, I am very happy with my new computer, Thanks.

Reviews.Title: Weird keyboard layout
Reviews.Author: Sergiy Zuban
Reviews.Content: Keyboard layout is very unusual. The biggest surprise is Ins key - its combined with Del key, so Fn+Del needs to be used instead

Reviews.Title: Amazing laptop no problems i use it for music production works great.
Reviews.Author: Eugenie Dorgilus
Reviews.Content: Amazing laptop no problems i use it for music production works great solid build quality beautiful display and keyboard and touchscreen no flaws

Reviews.Title: ASUS's worst disaster
Reviews.Author: David W.
Reviews.Content: Between the aggressive pre-installed bloatware (power management, drive control, and other hidden programs) and the lack of option to upgrade from Windows 8 to Windows 7, this laptop is unusable for much else other than checking email.  Windows 8 and 8.1 are nightmares in their own right, disallowing you to run many programs that would run fine on windows 7 (such as audio editing software and VSTi's), including many native 64 bit applications.  ASUS brings their own horrible bloatware to the table with hidden apps like Power4Gear which secretly overrides any power management options you set in Windows, ruining your work by putting your laptop to sleep or shutting it down without your permission when you least expect it and leaving you wondering what happened.I have been a big ASUS fan in the past, but this laptop has been a complete disaster for the last several weeks.  Even attempting to upgrade the special slim DVD drive to HDD storage requires special tools and professional level microsurgery involving over a dozen tiny T5 torx screws of varying lengths and complete removal of the entire back panel of the laptop (unlike most any other laptop).  If I wanted this much trouble upgrading a laptop, I would have bought an Apple.At this point, I may start over with something more friendly like an HP Elitebook.  Oh, and I'll be upgrading THAT one from Windows 8 to Windows 7!***Update***After considerable use, I must say this is hands down the worst computing experience I've had in 30 years.  When programs crash, they lock the entire system completely.  When the task manager is called via CTRL+ALT+DEL, it too crashes and freezes permanently (if it shows up at all, which is about a 60% chance).  Sadly, I've made a $1000 investment in this piece of garbage and am stuck unless I sell it to some poor unsuspecting person (which would be immoral).  Avoid this mistake and go with a company that offers support for Windows 7.***Another Update***This operating system is now preventing me from deleting files or folders I've created and placed in the My Documents folder or on the Desktop.  Restarting the computer has not solved the issue. Drive tests show the HDD to be fine, so it doesn't seem to be a hardware problem.  How bad does an OS have to be to have such a bug?  Because ASUS insists on supporting only WIN 8, the blame is theirs.  I used to be very supportive of ASUS.  All of my home-built and work-built towers sport ASUS motherboards.  They've completely lost my long term business by choosing to support Microsoft's wishes instead of their customers'.  If I had gone with anyone else, I might have had driver support for Win 7.  Avoid this laptop!!!***Final Update***Four different VSTi's (a few thousand dollar's worth) and a few other programs (some of which were 64 bit native) would not function properly in W8 or 8.1.  Amazon provided a refund.  Amazon is fantastic about that.  If all you are doing is browsing the internet or writing emails, this laptop will be fine for that.  Amazon is definitely the place to buy it for their return policy.  Power users or gamers, beware.
